results.title: Melbourne (no. 3)
results.brief_description: Film features quite general shots of Melbourne in the summer. This includes footage of the Great Ocean Road (including panoramas), a busy suburban pool and St. Kilda Beach. These sequences have a great, nostalgic ‘good time’ vibe to them, which is aided in part by the high-contrast film stock. There is also footage of one of Melbourne’s Gardens (possibly the Botanic), including blooming flowers and people looking at them. Nice shots of man burning leaves followed by the sun breaking through smoke haze and trees in garden. Two shots include views of St. Paul’s Cathederal and the Forum Theatre from the Yarra. Nice, Black and White ‘The End’.

results.title: Night out
results.brief_description: A young man is savagely bashed when he visits a toilet beat for sex. The assault forces a reassessment of the relationship he has with his boyfriend, as well as resulting in a self-examination of his own needs and desires. “Night out” is an intense Australian short that is as much about the intricacies and uncertainties of contemporary sexual relationships as it is about the violation and humiliation of physical assault. Official entry in the “Un Certain Regard” section of the 1990 Cannes Film Festival.

results.title: Mr Wasinski's Song
results.brief_description: While visiting an ear doctor Mr Wasinski discovers that his deafness is linked to a frightening childhood experience. During his consultation the doctor discovers gauze buried deep within his ear canal and upon its removal Mr. Wasinski becomes vulnerable to a barrage of repressed childhood memories. Having lived as a child in Poland during Nazi occupation Mr. Wasinski’s deafness marks the loss of his innocence as a child when separated from his parents during a desperate attempt to escape. The vivid memories suppressed with the aid of his deafness prove a challenge to an aging man who seeks distance from his childhood experiences. Stars Bruce Kerr as Mr Wasinski.

results.title: Letters from Poland
results.brief_description:
In Sydney in 1950 a young Polish woman waits for the arrival of Tadek, her prospective husband. Working as a night cleaner in a city office, she strikes up a casual friendship with the nightwatchman and waits for Tadek.
Cast features Martin Vaughan. Photography and editing by Martha Ansara.

results.title: Kicking on
results.brief_description: Using the great Australian sporting tradition of Aussie rules as a catalyst to explore gay male sexuality, this sweet, funny take on mateship and fair play on and off the field gives a whole new meaning to the term ‘holding the man’. Kicking on ultimately highlights the intimate spaces men create for each other that allow for physical contact and a dogmatic loyalty that in any other name would be called love.

results.title: Promise
results.brief_description: The tale of an old woman overseeing her grand-daughter making some damper when she is asked how it came to be that she was betrothed at a young age.

results.title: Puppenhead
results.brief_description: A Berlin puppet maker named Goethe takes his clockwork puppet knife-throwing act to New York. It is 1934 and a Nazi spy is watching him. A wickedly funny black comedy that quotes from Metropolis and Caligari, this short animation captures what was so good in German Expressionism- that eerie feeling of a world out of whack.

results.title: Passing through
results.brief_description: A young family on their way to visit relatives pass through an old gold mining town. As the woman begins to delve into memories of her childhood, the family leave to continue their journey. Has she missed the opportunity to discover the secrets of the past?

results.title: Nice coloured girls
results.brief_description: Nice Coloured Girls contrasts the relationship between Australian First nations women and white men in the past and the present. The film juxtaposes contemporary images of black women taking advantage of a white man with voice over extracts from early journals of white settlers and sailors, in order to question the validity of conventional white history and to deny the image of First Nations people as passive and powerless.

results.title: My colour, your kind
results.brief_description: A young girl, incarcerated in a dormitory, escapes to her rightful place in the world. During the journey she recollects her life and the treatment she has endured. In My Colour, Your Kind director Danielle Mclean uses her experience as a fair skinned First Nations person to explore the notion of First Nations identity.
